results.title: Sadek: speaking English
results.creator_credit: Michael Robertson, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
A biographical account of an Egyptian migrant, Sadek. The film discusses the adult education classes he attends, and the problems he has to face with his limited knowledge of English Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Saddam Hussein: the godfather of Iraq
results.creator_credit: Richard Hughes, Mark Rowland, Carlton International, Mentorn International and Reel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous lives”.
Born in 1937 into poverty and a fatherless home, Saddam Hussein was raised by his military uncle who fought against the British, instilling in his nephew a fierce nationalism, especially for Tsuni Arabs. Following a period of exile in Nassar, Hussein returns to Iraq, marries, and assumes a number of key positions in the governing Bath party. His penchant for violent political tactics appears early in his career, as he ruthlessly sets about destroying non Tsuni’s to secure a Bath party majority. His ability for self preservation and fierce nationalism also shows through as he publicly decries Europe and Russia while secretly carrying out deals with them. The 8 year war between Iran and Iraq is covered, as well as the ensuing war with Kuwait as Iraq is left financially bankrupt and geographically desolate after the war. The war against Kuwait would cease thanks to Operation Desert Storm, but with a high cost to civilian casualties. Regardless of the polarisation between those who view him as villain or hero, this documentary effectively conveys a leader who is, above all else, a ruthless survivor. Narrated by Lucy Longhurst.

results.title: Sad song of yellow skin
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Michael Rubbo
results.brief_description: A film about the people of Saigon as seen through the experience of three young American journalists who, in 1970, explored in their own way the consequences of war and of the American presence. It is not a film about the Vietnam war, or the rights or wrongs of it, but about the people who lived on the fringe of battle. The views of the city are arresting; but away from the shrines and the open-air markets lay another city, swollen with refugees and war orphans, where every inch of habitable space was covered. (Seven awards, including: Melbourne, Toronto, Robert J. Flaherty.)

results.title: Sacred vandals
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission. Creative Development Branch, Japan Foundation and Solrun Hoaas
results.brief_description: A film about women who follow their obsessions, taking dreams and illnesses as signs that they must find places in nature - rocks, trees, groves - that have special connection with their ancestors. They challenge the established order of things on the small depopulated island of Hatoma (Japan) and exert their spiritual power and leadership through subversive means. Focuses on three women, all of whom left the island long ago, but still retain a strong attachment to it, and who return to it regularly to perform their rituals.

results.title: Sacred sites
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza narrates this exploration of the Australian Aborigine’s relationship to his sacred sites. Several sites are visited with their guardians who explain the importance of maintaining the sites and protecting them from the tourist, mining and agricultural industries. Sites visited include, Merella Cave, W.A., Uluru, Alice Springs, Guru Guru Cave, W.A. and Milbrodale, N.S.W. There are also extensive interviews with Charles Perkins.

results.title: Sacred sex (E)
results.creator_credit: Triple Image, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Cynthia Connop
results.brief_description: The tantric tradition of sensual spirituality was an esoteric and mystical religious tradition which flourished in Ancient India and China. The tantric rites of sexuality are now finding a new wave of adherents among the “new agers” of the post-industrial West. This video explores the sexual research and experimentation taking place in cities such as Berlin, New York, Aspen and San Francisco by western people attempting the difficult reconciliation of erotic desires and spiritual fulfilment when they have been raised in a Christian culture which fundamentally opposes the spirit and the body. From a “Sluts and Goddess” workshop hosted by famous dominatrix Annie Sprinkler, to a “Rebirthing and Sexuality” conference in Hawaii, “Sacred Sex” explores the new forms of pagan and Eastern philosophies being popularised in the West.

results.title: Sacred hearts
results.creator_credit: Reality Productions, Dee Dee Glass and Barbara Rennie
results.brief_description: The torment, fear and severe discipline of impressionable schoolgirls at a Catholic orphanage in wartime Britain are brought vividly to the screen in “Sacred hearts”. Sister Thomas, (Anna Massey) is a major contributor to the atmosphere of intellectual, sexual and emotional repression at the convent school, where no signs of affection are tolerated. Excellently acted and constructed, this film exposes some of the myths and rituals which make up our perceptions of convent schools. The cast also includes Katrin Carlidge and Oona Kirsh.

results.title: Sacred Heart College for boys (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Place Where Books Are Kept”.
Examines new techniques and attitudes towards the total library services in a Catholic boarding school for boys. Emphasises centralised resources, individualised study and production of new teaching aids. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: Sacred groves [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Celts”.
The third in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000, this time with a focus on the Celts of Great Britain, Ireland and Wales and the ancient pagan religion of Druidism and its translation into the present day. The program discusses the fertility rights, rituals and burial rights that formed a large part of Celtic folk tradition and their mythology about the world after death with a focus on archaeological findings of riches and human remains in burial mounds as well as in peat bogs throughout Wales. The foundation of our present day Halloween in the ancient Celtic Feast of the Dead, where the earthly and supernatural world were said to intersect with nightmarish possibilities, is given as a striking example of a softened contemporary translation of ancient folklore. To this end a study is also made of the present day translation of Celtic religion, seen as a fairly removed version of the powerful Druidism of ancient times where, firmly routed in an engagement with nature, Druids were trained for twenty years to take their position in the highest priestly caste of the three orders and where great importance was placed on poetic Bards, sacrifice and no less than 200 gods and goddesses. The Druids’ fearful appearance to the Romans is also detailed, along with the stories of Druid rebellion against Roman invasion, let down in the end by lack of organisation against the most disciplined army of the world at that time and resulting in many elements of Druidism being banned or encapsulated in Catholicism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

The third in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000, this time with a focus on the Celts of Great Britain, Ireland and Wales and the ancient pagan religion of Druidism and its translation into the present day. The program discusses the fertility rights, rituals and burial rights that formed a large part of Celtic folk tradition and their mythology about the world after death with a focus on archaeological findings of riches and human remains in burial mounds as well as in peat bogs throughout Wales. The foundation of our present day Halloween in the ancient Celtic Feast of the Dead, where the earthly and supernatural world were said to intersect with nightmarish possibilities, is given as a striking example of a softened contemporary translation of ancient folklore. To this end a study is also made of the present day translation of Celtic religion, seen as a fairly removed version of the powerful Druidism of ancient times where, firmly routed in an engagement with nature, Druids were trained for twenty years to take their position in the highest priestly caste of the three orders and where great importance was placed on poetic Bards, sacrifice and no less than 200 gods and goddesses. The Druids’ fearful appearance to the Romans is also detailed, along with the stories of Druid rebellion against Roman invasion, let down in the end by lack of organisation against the most disciplined army of the world at that time and resulting in many elements of Druidism being banned or encapsulated in Catholicism.
